title: Monday, 18th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hi. Hello. Good morning. Etc.

wayneJ Hello
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily etc.

Otter Hello friends.
Manxish Morning all
BE11:04am

Here's a story to get us started.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-852d-d8b934ff5ffa

Swedish Chef Good morning. May must think the population are innumerate. She may well have a point.
BE11:04am

The UK financial regulator is to begin a review of the EU rules that changed how asset managers pay for the research they use to make investment decisions.

The Financial Conduct Authority, the City regulator, is concerned about inconsistencies in the interpretation and application of the Mifid II regulations, which came into force in January.

Shrink Morning.
BornCynic Morning
BE11:06am

.... which I guess is what a regulator does. Regulates things. And after regulations are put in place the regulator regulates whether the regulations are being followed regularly.

The Bernard Morning!
11:06 am
BE11:06am

“The costs of research packages offered by some of the big banks are totally out of whack with pricing elsewhere in the market,” said Joshua Maxey, managing director of Third Bridge, an independent research company, who welcomed the FCA probe.

“There are questions over whether some of the pricing packages for research could be viewed as an inducement and contrary to the Mifid rules.”

BE11:07am

I wonder where Joshua Maxey, managing director of Third Bridge, an independent research company, is referring to when he says "elsewhere in the market"?

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and assorted people
Swedish Chef Wonder if we will see a regulation effort from England this eve.
The Bernard Any comment on Nexans?
Shinshin Pricing is tricky though isn't it. If you do have 1000 clients then $10k prob is a fair reflection of your cots, if not the utility avalue of the product.
BE11:08am

Anyway, I've yet to see any benefit whatsoever to anyone from Mifid II.

Shinshin Versus an independent who can't scale to more than 50 clients and so has to charge $100k+. But there is clearly imlicit cross-sub going on at the larger shops.
Stateless Pricing is always impossible when the marginal cost of the product is 0.
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Costs are minimal in the scheme of things and research is mostly maintenance.

#REF! Research is maintenance until a company falls over, then buy side participants wants it to work out what on earth's happening...
BE11:10am

The most important bit of 99% of research notes is the phone number at the top. But I guess shoving that conclusion into a Powerpoint presentation will keep someone in the FCA busy for six months.

undefined
#REF! FCA were warned, if MIFID II goes ahead as planned, independent views will shrink, analysts will always have an eye on getting IB clients... and oh wait look that's occured
DJ Norwegian and Lufthansa?
11:11 am
BE11:11am

So ........... where first? Actual bids or fantasy ones?

BE11:12am

The latter's probably more interesting.

Aviva PLC (AV.:LSE): Last: 514.00, up 11.6 (+2.31%), High: 517.00, Low: 506.00, Volume: 5.19m
11:11 am
RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 657.80, up 5.8 (+0.89%), High: 665.00, Low: 655.40, Volume: 694.03k
The Bernard PW at Nexans?
BE11:13am

This is on the Sunday Times speculating aloud that there might be interest in the UK from Allianz

BE11:13am

https://www.thetim...-b8aa-6e92c706c88b

11:14 am
BE11:14am

As well as Zurich, of course, which was the bandit rumour of choice a few months ago. Or maybe even QBE.

BE11:14am

All of which follows this Bloomberg story saying similar things on Friday: https://www.bloomb...ps-market-guessing

wayneJ MIFID II is extremely important - yet another way to suppress smaller fund managers.
BE11:15am

Market seems to have decided Aviva's the more plausible target, which is slightly surprising as it'd take a cash call.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

As per JP Morgan Caz:

BE11:15am

Allianz reported 1Q18 225% solvency 2 ratio vs a 180-220% target range,
and at our conference on 30 May said that it had the capacity to issue €10bn restricted Tier 1 debt. Allianz also said that in the current environment the minimum floor is 170% Solvency 2 ratio and that the group starts derisking around 180% Solvency 2 ratio. Allianz leverage at 1Q18 was 26%. We estimate that Allianz’s excess relative to the 180% low end of the solvency 2 target range is €14bn. And we estimate half ie €7bn could potentially be monetized to fund a deal.

Playing FTSE BE: That BBG article is dated 12 Jun (Tues) not Fri
BE11:16am

Aviva market cap is the equivalent of €23bn and assuming the usual offer premium of 30% that would be a total potentially of €30bn. Aviva has we calculate 33% leverage. We assume in our calculation that Allianz would issue €10bn Tier 1 debt and €13bn of fresh equity. We estimate that an approach on this basis would potentially raise Allianz’s leverage from 26% to 35% and dilute its Solvency 2 ratio to 212%.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

RSA's much more consumable.

BE11:16am

(@Playing FTSE: THANKS FOR THAT!)

BE11:17am

RSA market cap is the equivalent of €7.7bn and assuming the usual offer premium of 30% that would be a total potentially of €10bn. RSA has we calculate 19% leverage. We assume in our calculation that Allianz would issue €3bn Tier 1 debt. We estimate that an approach on this basis would raise Allianz’s leverage from 26% to 29% and dilute its Solvency 2 ratio to 219%

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Also note that Allianz has said in the past that its priority is non-life

BE11:17am

Which RSA is, and Aviva isn't.

BE11:19am

Aviva's 60% life. Anyway, we've no idea what if anything Allianz is going to buy and I don't think anyone else does either.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Including, possibly, Oliver Bäte.

undefined
BE11:20am

Nexans? Sure, I guess.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Profit warning.

BE11:20am

Guiding for consolidated EBITDA around €350m, from €411m last year, in spite of sales remaining stable.

BE11:21am

Consensus was for €404m.

Playing FTSE Cobham had quite a jump after an MS upgrade
11:21 am
BE11:21am

The warning is also quite shortly after Nexans lost its CEO.

Punter Not new news, financial regulation tends to increase prices for customers and restrict choice
BE11:22am

Blame goes to delays in high voltage projects, weak activity in land
high voltage generally, and a big one-off tied to a court case.

BE11:23am

Shares have already been absolutely smashed over the past six months, down from e50 to e35ish.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

And trading quite close to book value, so you can make an "in the price" argument.

BE11:24am

Which is what Kepler does.

BE11:24am

We see Nexans’s sustainable group margins at between 4.5% and 5%
currently. Applying a 10x EV/EBIT and 6.5x EV/EBITDA on the revised
2018 forecast would support a fair value between EUR31 and EUR33 per
share. Upside will hinge on the appointment of a new leadership team and
greater visibility and confidence in 2019 forecasts. Nexans may fall into
“Deep Value” territory before opportunity arises for investors on a
reasonable risk-reward basis. Buy, TP EUR48 (based on WACC 8.1% and
multiples).

11:25 am
undefined
cracklenpop I'd play Dier ahead of Henderson, Rose before Young and Rashford instead of Alli….
BE11:25am

And so, Cobham.

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 131.30, up 6.95 (+5.59%), High: 134.05, Low: 128.35, Volume: 4.32m
Mouselet "financial analysis" is a weird perversion of journalism done by people with more pay and a less good moral code
11:27 am
BE11:28am

This is Morgan Stanley turning positive. Balance sheet fixed, margins can normalise, blah blah.

BE11:28am

We think current management have stabilised performance, with necessary costs sunk and measures taken to aid operational delivery. With multi-year upcycles beginning in core defence and aerospace markets, and other niche exposures appearing to be atF or close to the bottom, we see consensus underpinned. We model EBITA margins to improve to 13.5% in 2020 (cons 12.6%), against medium term targets of 12-14%.
Earnings potential beyond 2020 not in the price. Structural headwinds in the portfolio had largely played out by 2015, when Cobham generated 16% margins.
This includes underperforming businesses that have since been divested. We view 16% as closer to normalised margins, and see scope for them to grind higher and support EBITA growth. On 10x 2020e EBITA, we think little of this is priced in for a business returning to ~20% ROCE and ~100% FCF conversion.

BE11:29am

What's most surprising in all this, at least to me, is the FCF stuff.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

By 2020 we forecast Cobham to be sustainably generating ~6.5% of the current market cap a year in FCF with ~£200m of net cash on the balance sheet. We estimate that Cobham could return ~15-20% of the current market cap to shareholders and keep leverage at ~1x ND/EBITDA.

BE11:30am

Rescue rights issue in 2017, return 20% of its market cap in 2020.

BE11:30am

I mean, okay.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Oh, and Goldman's Chris Hallam's fired off a quick "we respectfully disagree" note.

BE11:32am

He remains sell. Sure, margins are going the right direction but risk-reward still ain't good, he says.

Tom Dalgleish Slow day............but I at least am watching on
Tax Realist Where do analysts get this 30% avg premium from...so lazy....more like 40% plus for bigger deals
BE11:32am

At a 12% 2020 EBIT margin (+200bp vs. 2017), COB LN still only offers a 5% FCF 2020E yield vs. sector average at 7% (a 14% margin would also put it at less than 6% FCF yield). New management does not have a margin improvement track record and the US Air Force is still saying Cobham’s largest program is well behind schedule. Through rest of the year, there is therefore scope for additional product penalties.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:34am

Hmmmmmmmmmm .................

Sirius Minerals PLC (SXX:LSE): Last: 32.10, down 1.2 (-3.60%), High: 33.42, Low: 31.80, Volume: 11.09m
11:34 am
BE11:34am

.............................................................. hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.

BE11:34am

That's on three times the average volume.

chad_john Uh oh...
Mouselet Sirius Minerals are the guys with the very deep potassium mine in Middlesbrough?
BE11:35am

Censored

11:35 am
undefined
BE11:35am

Sticking with miners for a moment ....

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 377.30, down 4 (-1.05%), High: 383.75, Low: 375.15, Volume: 11.41m
FATDAZ @Tax realist its an old market rule of thumb an from a traders standpoint it was and is used t give a back of envelope expectation of take out prices but of course each situation is different and one must discount that on a case by case basis
11:36 am
BE11:36am

So, this came out late on Friday.

BE11:36am

https://home.treas...ss-releases/sm0417

Pharma @Mouselet, middle of the North York moors I think. Middlesbrough would be easy (no objections likely to turning the whole area into an open-cast mine)
BE11:36am

Treasury Sanctions Fourteen Entities Affiliated with Corrupt Businessman Dan Gertler Under Global Magnitsky

11:36 am
BE11:36am

The 14 Gertler-affiliated entities OFAC designated today are: Moku Mines D’or SA, Moku Goldmines AG, Fleurette Energy I B.V., Fleurette Africa Resources I B.V., African Trans International Holdings B.V., Fleurette African Transport B.V., Oriental Iron Company SPRL, Iron Mountain Enterprises Limited, Sanzetta Investments Limited, Almerina Properties Limited, Interlog DRC, Kitoko Food Farm, Karibu Africa Services SA, and Ventora Development Sasu.

BE11:37am

Now, the interesting name there is Ventora

BE11:38am

And unless I'm mistaken, Ventora is the one Glencore is proposing to pay in the sanction-skirting deal they announced last week.

Tax Realist @FATDAZ You would hope analysts would have better access to good data than "rule of thumbs" in their research notes.
FATDAZ @Tom Dalgliesh macro calendar gets busier as we move trough the week :)
11:38 am
BE11:39am

So, if Glencore does pay the cash into the Ventora vehicle, does that mean the US goes after it?

DJ SXX profit warning incoming?
BE11:39am

That'd be an interesting development. The assumption last week was that Glencore had some kind of unofficial blessing from the US authorities

chad_john Some whopper sells there
FATDAZ @Tax yes but wouldn't be surprised if that 30% figure finds it way into models as a starting point.
BE11:40am

(@DJ: "profit"?)

chad_john (according to ADVFN data, obviously not certain to be sells)
Dec69 - Skeptic @be I'm speculating here but I'm of the mind Glencore know Gertlers case is solid and there's a real risk if they can't make payment then those assets are going to be solid to a Chinese entity and Glencore's asset value written to Zero. Tip for Glencore don't try and circumvent US Sanctions with an FX Transaction. If that's what they did, the smart cookies at the treasury will be collecting a proverbial ton of bricks to come down on them.
Dec69 - Skeptic Sold not solid*
11:41 am
BE11:41am

.... the idea being that if Dan takes back the assets from Glencore they'll eventually end up with the Chinese, and the US probably doesn't want the Chinese to take that much of the battery supply chain

BE11:42am

Friday's sanctioning of the Ventora vehicle would suggest to the idle viewer that things are rather less friendly than they might initially appear.

BE11:43am

Oh, and before we move on from miners we best mention the new SA code.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Draft Mining Charter. Again, came out late on Friday. 30 day consultation. Marginal positives but still not great overall for the industry, is the response.

BE11:44am

Here's Investec.

BE11:44am

Several improvements compared to the 2017 Mining Charter. These include clarity on the recognition of historical BEE transactions, longer transitional
periods for new and increased requirements, distributions to host communities and employees calculated on EBITDA rather than turnover as well as clarity on pending mining rights applications.
 Recognition of continuing consequences is a positive surprise. The draft 2018 Charter recognises historical BEE transactions where the right holder achieved a minimum of 26% before the commencement of the 2018 Mining Charter. A positive and welcome surprise, in our view, considering the DMR’s appeal against the granting of the declaratory order during April 2018.

Pharma @BE assuming rational and consistent behaviour from the US government at the moment is optimistic.
11:44 am
BE11:45am

Lower impact on existing mining rights even with the top-up clause. Most
mining companies achieved the 26% BEE shareholding in the past and do
qualify for the recognition of continuing consequences. However, this recognition is not transferable and lapses upon mining right renewal. We estimate that all companies under our coverage with exposure to SA have between 17 and 22 remaining years of current mining rights with the exception of the 9 years of Sibanye Stillwater’s gold division. This suggests a longer period before the transition to new requirements stipulated under new mining rights. We estimate a minimal dilution in 5 years if the 30% top-up requirement is retained.

Dec69 - Skeptic US Sanctions have been walked back over a metals company recently so I'm sure Glencore are screaming quietly in DC asking for some political and financial respite. The odds for this one might be harder to justify than aluminium...
BE11:45am

Concerns about new mining rights requirements. These include the nontransferable free carried interest of 10% for both qualifying employees and host communities; and the 6-years allowance before the trickle dividend becomes mandatory measured with reference to the commencement of the mining right rather than the commencement of production. These include the recognition of continuing consequences which is dependent on value realisation by the BEE entrepreneur during the duration of the mining right. We believe these stipulations are more suitable for high value resources and do not consider the cyclicality of the commodities markets.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,709, down 8.6 (-0.50%), High: 1,736, Low: 1,693, Volume: 1.76m
11:45 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,671, up 0.8 (+0.05%), High: 1,680, Low: 1,654, Volume: 1.77m
undefined
chad_john @BE: If something notable is happening with Sirius and some market participants are already acting on it, surely it can be reported? Or not? Forgive my blissful ignorance.
BE11:48am

Hm..... looks like Stocks To Watch still isn't up on the FT site, for some reason. Here's a preview of what it says on Ocado.

Paper Chase @chad I was thinking roughly the same thing, while wondering if I'm just not clever enough to figure out the implication of the zippy face.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded Ocado to “underperform” from “buy” with a £10.20 price target.

BE11:49am

Ocado’s exclusive deal with Kroger in the US leaves limited potential for customer fulfilment centre wins over the next five years, so the stock will be more reliant going forward on smooth delivery with no room for disappointment, said Merrill. Ocado’s first “normalised” year of earnings is five years away, which puts the stock on an enterprise value of 16.6 times 2023 ebitda, said the broker.

BE11:49am

“Ocado is moving into a long execution phase and we will not see any significant benefits until 2020, at the earliest. With all recent news priced in, we see risk for the share price to be flat.”

11:49 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 1,007, down 33.5 (-3.22%), High: 1,023, Low: 1,001, Volume: 1.21m
undefined
BE11:51am

@ROTR, re Sirius, I've nothing to say beyond observing that the name seems to have been interesting to short seller types in the past.

DJ Ennismore were a big short in SXX previously
casapinos SXX has a chunk of CB's outstanding, maybe some conversions/sales?
11:53 am
BE11:53am

There's nothing on the tape or in the public domain right now. And I have no information whatsoever on whether we should expect anything on the tape or in the public domain in the short, medium or long term. I only note that, based on the move and the volume behind it, others may think they know differently.

chad_john Hmm... so it's only RAW on the long side?
undefined
Tom Dalgleish Potash is a tough gig as BHP knows in Canada
Paper Chase Right-o, thank you BE.
wayneJ But SXX has 'special potash' - apparently unique stuff - for very special customers....
BE11:56am

Nearly there. Nearly at the end of this most tedious of Mondays.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Haven't mentioned Virgin-Clydesdale

Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 346.70, down 8.3 (-2.34%), High: 363.90, Low: 344.40, Volume: 6.24m
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
CYBG PLC (CYBG:LSE): Last: 302.40, down 3.8 (-1.24%), High: 311.20, Low: 301.60, Volume: 4.31m
wayneJ CYBG held its ground and gets a good deal
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Bid agreed at the previously announced 5% premium, which erases instantly

Pharma BBC radio this morning said that Virgin Money was being bought by *two* banks. Bless.
BE11:59am

Think Virgin holders were hoping for a bump, but maybe for slightly better cost savings, which seem rather back-end loaded.

BE12:00pm

Still -- Ian Gordon's happy, having championed the idea in the first place.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We see the CYBG/Virgin Money combination as a classic “all-British” affair,
with eminently deliverable synergy benefits and hence value creation for both sets of shareholders. We see this as a cracking deal for CYBG shareholders. Whereas Virgin shareholders may be disappointed at the absence of a “bump”, the deal still offers a 16.3p (4.6%) premium to Friday’s close (plus a 2.3p dividend) and the opportunity to share in upside from the combination.

BE12:00pm

Cost synergies are estimated at £120m (c.12% of the combined cost base).
Additionally, development of Virgin Money’s digital bank is to be discontinued, offering further benefit from the removal of “duplication”. Moreover, we expect the Virgin brand to deliver positive revenue synergies for CYBG, especially in relation to its intention to expand the geographic reach of its SME business.

BE12:01pm

UBS is a bit more cautious.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

We believe it is a good deal for all shareholders if they believe in the synergy potential and benefit from growth opportunities available to a national full-service bank, including the RBS SME state aid process. With the combined entity serving c.6m retail and SMEs customers, we expect the VM acquisition will add to scale (both revenues and costs), provide a better service proposition for SMEs and lower funding costs, However, we have concerns around: i) this not fixing the problem of low deposit base as new entity will have pro-forma 117% loan to deposit ratio with the Term Funding Scheme accounting for c.12% of the loans; ii) IT system migration risks as seen at TSB.

BE12:02pm

We can ask again what the point is in challenger banks, but it's a tired theme.

undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

We made it. We got through this. Well done everyone.

Soundbuy Cheers all
BE12:03pm

Thanks for joining. Back tomorrow. Etc.

Swedish Chef BBC News also said that "more money for health" in Scotland & Wales. Joel Barnett turning in his grave. Most media still don't understand basic stuff like devolution.
